dataIdInfo.idAbs: Calculates statistics over a specified dimension of a variable in a multidimensional dataset, such as netCDF or HDF.

tool.name: GetVariableStatisticsOverDimension

param.name: in_file
param.dialogReference: The full path or URL of the multidimensional dataset.
param.pythonReference: The full path or URL of the multidimensional dataset.

param.name: variable
param.dialogReference: The variable for the statistic to be calculated over.
param.pythonReference: The variable for the statistic to be calculated over.

param.name: dimension
param.dialogReference: The dimension of the variable for the statistic to be calculated over.
param.pythonReference: The dimension of the variable for the statistic to be calculated over.

param.name: out_netcdf_file
param.dialogReference: The output netCDF file. The file will be a copy of the input multidimensional dataset with the new statistical variable appended.
param.pythonReference: The output netCDF file. The file will be a copy of the input multidimensional dataset with the new statistical variable appended. Filename should have extension .nc.

param.name: out_variable
param.dialogReference: The name the new statistical variable should be given. The name must not be equal to an empty string or the name of an existing variable in the dataset.
param.pythonReference: The name the new statistical variable should be given. Although optional, the name must not be equal to an empty string or the name of an existing variable in the dataset.

param.name: statistic_type
param.expression: {MEAN | MAXIMUM | MINIMUM | RANGE | STD | SUM | VARIANCE}
param.dialogReference:
Statistic type to be calculated.

  • MEAN — Calculates the mean (average) of the input variable over the given dimension (default).

  • MAXIMUM — Determines the maximum (largest value) of the input variable over the given dimension.

  • MINIMUM — Determines the minimum (smallest value) of the input variable over the given dimension.

  • RANGE — Calculates the range (difference between largest and smallest value) of the input variable over the given dimension.

  • STD — Calculates the standard deviation of the input variable over the given dimension.

  • SUM — Calculates the sum (total of all values) of the input variable over the given dimension.

  • VARIANCE — Calculates the variance (squared standard deviation) of the input variable over the given dimension.

If no statistic is selected, MEAN will be used by default.
param.pythonReference: Statistic type to be calculated. Valid types are {MEAN | MAXIMUM | MINIMUM | RANGE | STD | SUM | VARIANCE}.

tool.summary: Calculates statistics over a specified dimension of a variable in a multidimensional dataset, such as netCDF or HDF.
tool.usage:
• The output file will be a copy of the input dataset with the new statistical variable appended. This variable will have the same dimensions as the input variable less the dimension the statistic was calculated over.

  • This tool may be run multiple times to summarize a variable over multiple dimensions.

scriptExample.title: GetVariableStatisticsOverDimension example 1 (local dataset)
scriptExample.para: Calculates the mean value occurring in the pptx variable over the latitude dimension.
scriptExample.code:
import arcpy
# Import the supplemental toolbox. arcpy.ImportToolbox("c:/data/Multidimension Supplemental Tools.pyt")
input_file = "c:/data/netcdf/dataset.nc" output_file = "c:/data/netcdf/dataset_withmeanlat.nc"
arcpy.GetVariableStatisticsOverDimension_mds(input_file, "pptx", "lat", output_file, "pptx_MEANlat", "MEAN")

scriptExample.title: GetVariableStatisticsOverDimension example 2 (remote dataset)
scriptExample.para: Calculates the mean value occurring in the pptx variable over the latitude dimension.
scriptExample.code:
import arcpy
# Import the supplemental toolbox. arcpy.ImportToolbox("c:/data/Multidimension Supplemental Tools.pyt")
input_url = "http://www.opendap_server.com/data/dataset.nc" output_file = "c:/data/netcdf/dataset_withmeanlat.nc"
arcpy.GetVariableStatisticsOverDimension_mds(input_url, "pptx", "lat", output_file, "pptx_MEANlat", "MEAN")
